title: Quiz 3: School Health Programmes
description: Test on organizing, implementing, and evaluating health services for the school population.

questions.question: Which of the following are identified as basic needs of a school child? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Basic needs include a stable home, nutrition, freedom from fatigue, clothing, good sight/hearing, freedom from infection, safe water, and clean buildings.
questions.hint: Think about physiological and safety needs.

questions.question: Match the physical examination finding to the body part being assessed:
questions.explanation: Tinea capitis affects the head; Bitot's spots (Vit A deficiency) affect eyes; Fluorosis affects teeth; Spoon-shaped nails indicate iron deficiency.
questions.hint: Keratomalacia relates to vision; Fluorosis relates to dental.

questions.question: When inspecting the school classroom, which of the following is a key requirement?

options.text: Seats should be attached to each other.
Lighting should be dim to promote rest.
Well ventilated with adequate lighting; not overcrowded.
Students should not be able to see the blackboard to encourage listening.

questions.explanation: Classrooms should be clean, well ventilated, well lit, not overcrowded, and allow students to see the board and hear the teacher.
questions.hint: Think about the ideal learning environment.

questions.question: A ___BLANK___ approach is advocated in providing health services as school children are easy to reach and disseminate health messages.
questions.explanation: A school health approach is advocated because children are accessible and act as change agents.
questions.hint: The name of the program discussed in this section.

questions.question: Order the steps for organizing a school health programme:

items.text: Assess the problems of school children

questions.explanation: The logical flow is Assessment -> Goal Setting -> Implementation -> Evaluation.
questions.hint: You must know the problem before setting goals.

questions.question: During a physical exam, observing 'spoon shaped' nails is a sign of Vitamin A deficiency.
questions.explanation: Spoon-shaped nails indicate iron deficiency anaemia. Vitamin A deficiency manifests in the eyes (Bitot's spots, keratomalacia).
questions.hint: Vitamin A affects the eyes; Iron affects blood/nails.

questions.question: Which resource is primarily responsible for funding school health programmes in Kenya?
questions.explanation: Funding for school health programmes is mainly the responsibility of the government, supported by stakeholders.
questions.hint: Public health initiatives are usually state-funded.

questions.question: What is the purpose of maintaining cumulative records for each child?

options.text: To punish students with poor health.
To evaluate the effectiveness of school health services.

questions.explanation: Records are used for evaluation to determine if objectives (like number of pupils treated/referred) are being met.
questions.hint: Records are essential for monitoring and evaluation.

questions.question: What common fungal infection of the head should be checked for during a physical exam?
questions.explanation: Tinea capitis (ringworm of the scalp) is a common condition checked during head exams.
questions.hint: Also known as ringworm of the scalp.

questions.question: Which of the following are valid sources for assessing school health needs?
questions.explanation: Valid sources include clinic records, reports, health team discussions, teachers/parents/students, observations, and community leaders.
questions.hint: Look for data-driven or consultative sources.
